section-block.rac_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: This Shoe Needs a Foot

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Caedyn Melach and illustrated by Wook Jin Jung
section-block.rac_book_summary: A little shoe is lonely because it can’t find the foot that belongs in it. Some friendly animals try to help. Their own feet don’t fit, but they measure the shoe and are able to solve the problem.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about how they can measure how tall or how long something is, or how hot or cold it is outside.
Give children directions to follow, such as “Run to the tallest thing you see in the room,” or “Walk to the smallest red thing you can find.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read This Shoe Needs a Foot. This book is written by Caedyn Melach and illustrated by Wook Jin Jung.
Scout enjoys reading narratives about friends helping other friends. He can’t wait to see how the animals in this story help the shoe find a foot.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Which animals are trying to help the shoe find a foot?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the animals thinking when they see one shoe all alone? Why is it strange to see one shoe by itself?
What animals do you think are looking at the shoe? How can you tell what the animals are?
The shoe is empty, cold, and scared and is all alone.
How do you know the shoe is empty? Do you think the shoe would feel better if there was another shoe?
Look at the shoe. How do you think it feels? How can you tell?
Look at the foot trying on the shoe. Can you guess what animal this is? What do you notice about this animal’s foot? Are our feet round like the elephant’s foot?
What animal do you think this paw belongs to? Why doesn’t the shoe fit this animal?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Which animals are trying to help the shoe find a foot?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about how the animals measured the length of the shoe as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is the elephant or the fox trying to help the shoe find a foot?
The el_______ (elephant) is trying to help the shoe find a foot.
The elephant is trying to help the shoe find a foot.
Which of the animals have small feet?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children need to develop their gross motor skills so they can engage in age-appropriate physical activities and participate in activities that require body control. Children will begin to recognize various measurement scenarios, and incorporate concepts such as long and short into their movement repertoire.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Ask & Answer Questions
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children how important it is to ask and answer questions. Explain that we ask and answer questions to learn or share information. It’s also a good way to get answers to things we don’t understand. Encourage children to ask and answer questions throughout the day.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit This Shoe Needs a Foot. This book is written by Caedyn Melach and illustrated by Wook Jin Jung.
Clifford loves narratives about other animals. He’s going to ask questions about what the animals in the story do to help the shoe.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book and think of some questions we can ask and answer about the story to see the ask and answer questions Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How are the animal feet on these pages alike?
How are the animal feet on these pages different?
The animals tell the shoe not to cry. Why is the shoe crying? What questions could you ask the shoe about how it’s feeling? (MB)
Why can’t this animal’s foot fit in the shoe? What color is this animal’s fur? Does the shoe fit this animal? (MB)
How many feet do you see in the box at the top of the page? What is alike and what is different about these feet? (MB)
The child’s foot has something around it. What do you think that means? Do you think the shoe will fit? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: You can play Question Toss with children. You may want to provide some prompts for questions at first. Have children stand in a circle. Ask an easy question related to This Shoe Needs a Foot and then pass a ball to a child. That child holds the ball and answers the question. Then he or she asks a question of the next child, and then hands the ball to the child. The second child does the same thing—answers the question, and then asks a new one and passes the ball to another child. Continue until each child has had at least one turn of asking and answering a question.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how we can use a ruler to measure different things.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children are naturally curious. They like to ask questions as they try to understand the world around them. You can encourage this behavior by providing plenty of opportunities for them to inquire about what they see. Learning how to ask and answer questions will build skills that will last a lifetime. (Preschoolsteam.com/Inquiry thinking)

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children if they were able to make a prediction about whether the shoe will find a foot that fits.
Have children jump like frogs from one point to another. Put a piece of colored tape with their names when they get to the finish line. Then measure each child’s jump.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit This Shoe Needs a Foot written by Caedyn Melach and illustrated by Wook Jin Jung.
Scout the Squirrel likes to measure things. He likes this narrative because it talks about measuring. Scout thinks he can predict what happens at the end of the story.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s look at all of the feet on these pages. Let’s make a prediction: will any of these feet fit the shoe? How can you tell?
The animals need to find out how long the shoe is. They need to use a ruler to do that.
Have you used a ruler before? How did you use it?
The animals used the ruler to measure the shoe.
The numbers on the ruler tell us how long the shoe is. How long is the shoe?
The animals decide to measure their feet to see which of their feet would fit the shoe. Were any of the animals’ feet the right size?
What happened when the animals measured the child’s foot? Is it the same size as the shoe?
Did you guess what was going to happen at the end of the story?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We measure things to find out how big they are.
We measure things to find out if they will fit.
We measure things to find out how much we have.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about measuring things with a ruler.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do we measure things to find out how big or how important they are?
We measure things to find out how b_____ (big) they are.
We measure things to find out how big they are.
What can you use a ruler to measure?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Measuring Skills and Vocabulary Development
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children apply early concepts of measurement in many of their everyday activities. They begin to develop their vocabulary for measurement and comparison. Focus on words such as long and short, big and small, etc., during the week to make sure children build a working knowledge of measurement terms.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about different tools they can use to measure things. What do they use to measure how long something is or how hot it is outside?
Pick an object (e.g., a pencil) and have children walk around the room to find three things that are longer than the object. See who can find all the objects first.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Can Measure. It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout likes reading informational texts and learning about different tools used to measure things.
This Shoe Needs a Foot and I Can Measure both focus on ways that people can measure. Let’s see if we can find connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show This Shoe Needs a Foot cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the poster, and then use the prompts to discuss it.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: A ruler measures how long. How long is the shoe?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show page 11 of This Shoe Needs a Foot.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the picture of the scale? What is the child measuring? How can you tell which one is heavy?
How do you know which one is light?
Look at the picture of the girl with the measuring cup. I think the girl is measuring orange juice. What do you think she is measuring?
The hand is pointing to a thermometer that is measuring a hot temperature. What clothes do you wear when it is hot?

section.rac_body-text: Retell “Goldilocks and the Three Bears.” Discuss how Goldilocks tries to find a chair that is not too big or too small. Have children act as Goldilocks looking for the right chair. How could measuring the chair help Goldilocks? How could she measure a chair?
Provide a writing prompt about measuring something in the classroom, and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage multilingual learners to teach the rest of the class the words for measurement terms, such as tall, short, heavy, and light, in their home language. Children probably know these terms in their home language. In Spanish, for example, the word for tall is alto(a) when describing a tall person and bajo(a) when describing a short tree.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out measuring words, e.g., size, long and short, big and small, hot and cold, etc. Have children use their hands, arms, and bodies to show big and small, tall and short, wide and thin, light and heavy, and hot and cold.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book This Shoe Needs a Foot written by Caedyn Melach and illustrated by Wook Jin Jung.
This book is a narrative. That means it is a story that the author made up. In real life, we know that shoes and animals can’t talk. Scout loves to read made-up stories like this one.
This week we read about a shoe looking for the foot that belongs in it. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How did the animals help the shoe find the right foot?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The animals want to help the shoe who is lost. Let’s pretend we are helping someone who is lost. Say, “Can I help? What can I do?”
Can you guess which animal is trying on the shoe? Is the shoe too big or too small?
Can you tell which animal is trying on the shoe here? How can you tell what animal this is? Let’s pretend we are an octopus. Stand up and swim like an octopus under the ocean!
Let’s look at all of the feet on these pages. Which foot is too wide to fit in the shoe?
Which feet on these pages are too thin to fit in the shoe?
Look at the shoe. How do you think it feels? Why does it feel happy? Show me your happy face!
Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How did the animals help the shoe find the right foot?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The animals tried on the shoes.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about measuring different things in the classroom and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did the animals measure their feet or hands?
Use a ruler to measure your foot. How long is it?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children are born with the desire to connect with those around them. This week’s read aloud and activities allow plenty of opportunities to look at how people can work together to achieve a common goal, solve a mystery, or just help someone out. Be sure to stress that aspect as children retell the story of the little shoe.
